title: 109_s2475
content: The Act titled "Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community Act of 2006" establishes a commission. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community consists of 23 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, majority leader of the Senate, and minority leader of the Senate. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community consists of 23 members appointed by various leaders, with voting and nonvoting members appointed by different officials based on qualifications related to American Latino life, art, history, and politics. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community requires members with expertise in museum administration, fundraising for nonprofit institutions, teaching Latino culture at the postsecondary level, or studying the representation of American Latino art and culture at the Smithsonian Institution. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community seeks members with expertise in museum administration, fundraising for nonprofit institutions, teaching Latino culture at the postsecondary level, or studying the representation of American Latino art and culture at the Smithsonian Institution. Members should also have experience in the administration or planning of museums focused on ethnic, racial, or cultural groups in American history. The Commission to Study the Potential Creation of a National Museum of the American Latino Community focuses on functions related to museum administration, fundraising, teaching Latino culture, and studying American Latino art and culture at the Smithsonian Institution. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress with recommendations for establishing and maintaining a National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC. They will also develop fundraising plans and examine issues related to the Museum in consultation with the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress on issues related to the establishment of a National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC, including fundraising and potential locations for the Museum. The National Capital Planning Commission and the Commission of Fine Arts are discussing the establishment of a National Museum of the American Latino Community in Washington, DC. Key considerations include the Museum's location within the Smithsonian Institution, governance structure, and engagement with the American Latino community in the design process. Legislation will be proposed to the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure based on the recommendations from the reports submitted. The Commission will submit recommendations to various committees for a legislative plan to create the Museum. Additionally, a national conference will be convened to engage individuals in advancing the Museum's mission. The Commission will convene a national conference on the Museum, bringing together individuals dedicated to advancing American Latino life, art, history, and culture within 9 months of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. The Secretary of the Interior provides administrative services, facilities, and funds for the Commission's functions. Commission members not employed by the government receive compensation and travel expenses as determined by the Secretary of the Interior. The Commission must submit final reports, plans, and recommendations within 18 months of the Act's enactment and terminate within 30 days of submission. $2.1 million is authorized for fiscal year 2007 and $1.1 million for fiscal year 2008 for Commission activities.
